name: The Mecca Center
mission: The Fund is formed as an endowment in support of the Muslim Educational Cultural Center of America DBA The Mecca Center
theoryOfChange: By providing comprehensive Islamic education (Quran Institute, Sunday School) and spiritual guidance (Imams, Youth MVMT), the center aims to build a model Muslim character and a sense of civic responsibility in the community.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: fi_sabilillah (+5)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 36/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, humanitarian cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Track and report beneficiary counts to enable cost analysis
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

judge_issues.message: The rationale does not mention the significant risk deduction due to the small board size, which is a key factor affecting the overall score.
ZAKAT-ELIGIBLE claimed but no explicit zakat evidence found on website
Extremely high working capital (124.0 months) may indicate hoarding or data error

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Mecca Center Endowment Fund earns 57/100 due to strong alignment and moderate impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://meccacenter.org/zakat (Source: https://meccacenter.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: The Mecca Center Endowment Fund is a registered 501(c)(3) organization associated with EIN 84-5191730.
The organization is Zakat-eligible and follows specific zakat policies for distribution.
The organization reported Total Revenue of $1,523,429 and maintains a program expense ratio of 91.1%.
The Fund is formed as an endowment in support of the Muslim Educational Cultural Center of America.
The organization operates the Sunday School program as part of its core educational mission.
The Mecca Quran Institute (MQI) is a primary program supported by the organization's activities.
The charity offers multiple donation options for donors to support its endowment and programs.
The organization provides volunteer opportunities and engagement programs for the youth community.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial health and high program spending, though its total score is tempered by limited external impact data and low data confidence.
areas_for_improvement: Limited public data regarding specific program outcomes and impact metrics
Low data confidence due to reliance on baseline financial filings

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization shows high alignment for Muslim donors as it is Zakat-eligible and supports essential humanitarian and religious education needs [2][9]. It maintains a strong track record of community engagement through volunteer opportunities and youth programs [10].
dimension_explanations.impact: The Fund focuses on capacity building by securing the long-term viability of educational programs like the Mecca Quran Institute [4][7]. While it maintains a high program expense ratio of 91.1% and substantial working capital of 124.0 months, specific evidence of beneficiary outcomes remains limited in public filings [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Mecca Center Endowment Fund provides long-term financial stability and capacity building for Islamic educational and cultural programming.
strengths: Exceptional liquidity with 124.0 months of working capital
Highly efficient fundraising operations at $0.00 per $1 raised
baseline_narrative.summary: The Mecca Center Endowment Fund is established to provide permanent financial support for the Muslim Educational Cultural Center of America (The Mecca Center) [1][4]. The Fund sustains critical community initiatives including the Mecca Quran Institute (MQI) and the Sunday School program [4][5].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial health and high program spending, though its total score is tempered by limited external impact data and low data confidence.

areas_for_improvement.detail: The organization currently operates with a <cite id="14">board of only 2 members</cite>, which is below best practice for oversight.
There is <cite id="15">limited public data regarding specific beneficiary counts</cite> or external impact evaluations.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization has not been formally evaluated by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's 20-year track record and MUHSEN certification provide some qualitative assurance of operational quality.
risk_factors: <cite id="14">Small board size (2 members)</cite> limits independent oversight.
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="14">governance and transparency</cite>.

confidence.notes: While financial efficiency is high, the low board size and lack of transparency metrics result in a low overall confidence score.

alignment.explanation: The fund is <cite id="16">zakat-eligible</cite> and serves critical asnaf categories including <cite id="17">the poor and needy (fuqara and masakin)</cite>.

credibility.explanation: Donors can verify the fund's financial health through <cite id="3">official Form 990 filings</cite>, though overall <cite id="15">data confidence remains low</cite> due to limited third-party ratings.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="14">expand its board size</cite> and publish annual impact reports.

impact.explanation: The fund is highly efficient, with a <cite id="5">91.1% program ratio</cite> and <cite id="11">exceptional liquidity</cite> for capacity building.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="15">tracking and reporting beneficiary counts</cite> to enable cost-per-beneficiary analysis.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Internal tracking and theory of change

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Solely supports the operations and programs of The Mecca Center.

rich_narrative.headline: The Mecca Center Endowment Fund provides long-term financial stability and capacity building for Islamic educational and cultural programming.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize the long-term institutional stability of American Muslim communities and prefer an endowment model with zero fundraising overhead.
donor_motivations: Want to ensure the future of Islamic education in the US
Value high program expense ratios and low overhead
Prefer supporting established community institutions with deep roots
giving_considerations: Donations support an endowment rather than immediate emergency relief
Governance is centralized within a very small board
Limited quantitative impact data is available publicly
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-frequency impact reporting or those who prefer organizations with large, independent boards of directors.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a clear theory of change and internal tracking, but a lack of external evaluations or beneficiary data.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The fund creates impact by providing a permanent capital base that generates income to subsidize Islamic educational programs and community services.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that endowment payouts are effectively translating into educational and spiritual growth for the community.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As an endowment, the fund has unlimited capacity to absorb capital to increase its annual payout for community services.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by an <cite id="10">unusually low fundraising cost</cite> and <cite id="11">massive reserve capacity</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Similar religious and educational service model

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focus on community development and education

strengths.detail: The fund directs <cite id="5">91.1% of its expenses toward programs</cite> and maintains a <cite id="10">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>.
As an endowment, the organization holds <cite id="11">124.0 months of working capital</cite> in working capital, ensuring long-term stability.
Operating since <cite id="12">its founding in 2004</cite>, the organization has built a 20-year history of serving the Muslim community.

strengths_deep_dive: The Mecca Center Endowment Fund demonstrates a high degree of fiscal responsibility, characterized by its <cite id="10">zero-cost fundraising model</cite> and a <cite id="5">91.1% program expense ratio</cite>. This efficiency is paired with a clear <cite id="13">documented theory of change</cite> focused on capacity building for Islamic institutions. The fund's ability to maintain <cite id="11">over 124.0 months of working capital</cite> positions it as a stable pillar for the community, capable of weathering economic fluctuations while continuing to fund <cite id="2">MQI and Sunday School initiatives</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: The Mecca Center Endowment Fund serves as the long-term financial backbone for the Muslim Educational Cultural Center of America, ensuring the sustainability of Islamic education and community services in the United States. Established to provide <cite id="1">permanent financial support for The Mecca Center</cite>, the fund enables the operation of cornerstone programs such as the <cite id="2">Mecca Quran Institute and Sunday School</cite>. In 2023, the organization reported <cite id="3">total revenue of $1,523,429</cite>, representing a significant <cite id="4">3-year revenue CAGR of 179.4%</cite>. This growth reflects a successful transition into a more robust endowment model. The organization maintains a <cite id="5">program expense ratio of 91.1%</cite>, which is notably higher than the <cite id="6">peer program ratio median of 89.7%</cite> for humanitarian and religious organizations. Furthermore, the fund operates with <cite id="7">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, ensuring that virtually every dollar contributed is preserved for the endowment's mission. Beyond financial management, the fund supports a diverse array of services including <cite id="8">youth programs, convert support, and special needs accommodations</cite>, the latter of which earned <cite id="9">Silver Certification from MUHSEN</cite> for accessibility and inclusion.
